content: British historian and academic **Karl Anthony Hack** is a British historian and academic, who specialises in the history of [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia), the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire), and of [insurgency](/wiki/Insurgency) and [counter-insurgency](/wiki/Counter-insurgency). Drawing on interviews with insurgents, his work has demonstrated the role of high-level [coercion](/wiki/Coercion) in winning post-war counter-insurgencies, and explored extreme violence and violence limitation. He has also carried out a wide range of public work, ranging across heritage, memory, the media and the courts. He is a professor of history at [The Open University](/wiki/Open_University) where he has also been head of history, and head of the School of History, Religious Studies, Sociology, Social Policy and Criminology . Prior to joining The Open University in 2006, he taught at the [National Institute of Education](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Education), at Singapore's [Nanyang Technological University](/wiki/Nanyang_Technological_University), from 1995 to 2006. ## Early life and education Karl Hack was born in 1966 at [RAF Hospital Changi](/wiki/Changi_Hospital), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). He was educated at [Hardye's School](/wiki/Thomas_Hardye_School) in [Dorchester](/wiki/Dorchester,_Dorset), [Dorset](/wiki/Dorset), starting when it was a state grammar and finishing after it had become a comprehensive school. He took the first year of the [Philosophy, Politics and Economics](/wiki/Philosophy,_Politics_and_Economics) [bachelor's degree](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree) course at [Keble College, Oxford](/wiki/Keble_College,_Oxford), before transferring to read [History](/wiki/History). He then undertook postgraduate research, initially at [Keble College, Oxford](/wiki/Keble_College,_Oxford), moving to [St Hugh's College, Oxford](/wiki/St_Hugh%27s_College,_Oxford) on the award of a Gateway Scholarship. He completed his [Doctor of Philosophy](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy) (DPhil) degree in 1995. ## Academic career From 1995 to 2006, he was an assistant and then an associate professor of history at the [Nanyang Technological University](/wiki/Nanyang_Technological_University) (NTU), in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), teaching a range of [Southeast Asian history](/wiki/History_of_Southeast_Asia). As part of NTU's [National Institute of Education](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Education) he visited Singapore secondary schools and [junior colleges](/wiki/Junior_college_(Singapore)), and provided services and advice to the [Ministry of Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)), [Singapore Tourism Board](/wiki/Singapore_Tourism_Board), and [Ministry of Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)). He also experimented with early versions of the '[flipped classroom](/wiki/Flipped_classroom)', moving lectures on subjects such as [Chinatown](/wiki/Chinatown,_Singapore) online in order to increase the quality and range of face to face teaching. He worked particularly closely with NTU colleague Dr Kevin Blackburn. Together they integrated [oral history](/wiki/Oral_history) projects on family and on place into the teaching of [Singapore history](/wiki/History_of_Singapore) and [social studies](/wiki/Social_studies), and collaborated on publications and heritage projects. In 2006, he moved to [The Open University](/wiki/Open_University), where he helped to chair the production of a new module, "Empire: 1492-1975 (A326)"., which has been delivered by blended online and traditional methods to several hundred students yearly since 2009. From 2009 to December 2015 he was director of the Ferguson Centre for Asian and African Studies, editing its series of online working papers. He has also served as head of the Open University History Department, and in August 2016 he became inaugural head of the new School of History, Religious Studies, Sociology, Social Policy and Criminology (HRSSC). In 2016 he also chaired production of an entirely online dissertation module, A329 The Making of Welsh History, which trialled new methods of direct authoring of online modules, and of involving students as co-educators in an intensive and continuous online learning community. The dissertations are online here. ## Public engagement Together with Dr Kevin Blackburn of [NTU](/wiki/Nanyang_Technological_University), Dr Hack led the historical consultancy behind the new Singapore heritage site, the [Johore Battery](/wiki/Johore_Battery), which opened in 2002. They also took the lead in organizing the 2005 *Forum with the Wartime Generation at the Singapore History Museum and The Japanese Occupation Conference*, which was open to students and the public at what is now known as the [National Museum of Singapore](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Singapore). He was also the Open University's lead academic on the [BBC](/wiki/BBC) series [*Empire*](/wiki/Empire_(2012_TV_series)) – which was first aired on BBC One from February to May 2012 as well as being issued as a DVD – producing a historical poster, of which more than 63,700 hard copies were distributed. The latter was expanded into the website "Selling Empire: The Empire Marketing Board". (*OpenLearn*, The Open University), which has informed public understanding of the [Empire Marketing Board](/wiki/Empire_Marketing_Board) in particular. Other radio and television work has included interviews for [Radio 4](/wiki/BBC_Radio_4)'s *Terror Through Time* series, and appearing on *Crisis in Malaya*, *Black Ops* episode 8, series 2 (2014), talking about the [Malayan Emergency](/wiki/Malayan_Emergency). In 2012 he was expert witness in the [Penang](/wiki/Penang) High Court, testifying on the historically contested and diverse ways and degrees to which people could be defined as ['communist'](/wiki/Communism) in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). He is also involved with the [Imperial War Museum](/wiki/Imperial_War_Museum) in a collaborative studentship, jointly supervising doctoral research on *The Impact of postwar counter-insurgency on the British military*. ## Personal life In 1989, Karl married Vanessa Jones. Together they have two daughters and one son. He is a member of Oxford Hawks Hockey Club and was formerly a member of Ceylon Sports Club, Singapore.[*citation needed*] ## Selected books - *Defence and decolonisation in Southeast Asia : Britain, Malaya and Singapore 1941-1967*.
